entry.et: Middle English, from Old English sang; akin to Old English singan to sing

def.dt: :the act or art of singing
:poetical composition
:a short musical composition of words and music
:a collection of such compositions
:a distinctive or characteristic sound or series of sounds (as of a bird, insect, or whale)
:a melody for a lyric poem or ballad
:a poem easily set to music
:a habitual or characteristic manner
:a violent, abusive, or noisy reaction put up quite a song
:a small amount sold for a song
:a theatrical performance (as a vaudeville performance) combining singing and dancing
:a long and often familiar statement or explanation that is usually not true or pertinent
:a group of related songs designed to form a musical entity

entry.et: from the opening verse: “The song of songs, which is Solomon's”

def.dt: :a collection of love poems forming a book in the Protestant canon of the Old Testament see bible table

:a collection of love poems forming a book in the canonical Jewish Scriptures and in the Roman Catholic canon of the Old Testament and corresponding to the Song of Solomon in the Protestant canon of the Old Testament see bible table
:a North American sparrow (Melospiza melodia of the family Emberizidae) that is brownish above and white below with brownish streaks on the breast and that has a melodious song
:an Old World thrush (Turdus philomelos of the family Turdidae) that is largely brown above with brown-spotted white underparts called also mavis throstle
:a usually through-composed song for solo voice and accompaniment compare folk song
:a song on a convivial theme appropriate for a group engaged in social drinking
:a song used to inspire enthusiasm usually during an athletic competition
